conclusion: Understanding the problem involves an ideal gas and a graph showing volume V and temperature T.
Graph has volume V on y-axis and temperature T on x-axis with points A, B, and C.
Point A is at (T₀, V₀), point B is at (T₀, 2V₀), and point C is along line from A to B.
Pressure in state A is P₀, temperature is T₀, need to find pressure in state B.
Line segment AB is vertical, temperature constant at T₀, volume increases from V₀ to 2V₀.
Extension of BC passes through origin, line has constant slope from B to C.
Using ideal gas law PV = nRT, n is constant since mass is constant.
From A to B, volume increases at constant temperature, isothermal process.
For isothermal process, P ∝ 1/V, so P_B = P₀ * (V₀ / 2V₀) = P₀ / 2.
Extension of BC passes through origin, slope of OC is V/T.
Equation of line OC is V = (V_B / T_B) * T.
Point B satisfies 2V₀ = (2V₀ / T_B) * T₀, so T_B = T₀.
Re-evaluating, P changes as V changes at constant T between A and B.
Verification using ideal gas equation: At A, P₀ * V₀ = nR T₀; At B, P_B * 2V₀ = nR T₀.
Point C is on line from A to B, extension of BC passes through origin.
Considering path from A to B via C as two separate processes.
